misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program is designed to read three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of the required five integer inputs for the sum-of-evens problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program should read initial velocity, final velocity, and time as doubles for an acceleration calculation.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly five integer values from the user, e.g., using nextInt() five times (possibly in a loop).
symptoms: Input prompt mentions v0, v1, and t instead of five integers
Uses nextDouble() three times instead of nextInt() five times
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to be implementing a different textbook problem (average acceleration) rather than the specified task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the prompt to ask for five integers and use nextInt() to read five separate integer values, storing each for processing.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All input-related code clearly targets an acceleration problem and uses three double reads instead of five integers.

evidence.note: Reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers required by the problem.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional to check for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even using a condition like n % 2 == 0, so it cannot filter and sum only even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that no conditional check is needed for this task, likely because they are solving a different problem.

No if-statement that checks parity of inputs
All read values are used directly in an acceleration formula instead

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add an if (n % 2 == 0) check inside the loop to ensure only even numbers are added to the running total.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no occurrence of modulo or any parity-based condition in the code.

evidence.note: Values are used directly in a formula; no conditional logic to check evenness is present.

misconceptions.name: Computes acceleration instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: Instead of maintaining an accumulator for the sum of even numbers and printing that sum, the program computes average acceleration and prints it.

Output message refers to "average acceleration" instead of sum of even numbers
No accumulator variable that aggregates input values
